href="http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/26/elida-arrizza-priming-your-wordpress-canvas-essentials-for-a-solid-foundation/"><img alt="Elida Arrizza: Priming Your WordPress Canvas – Essentials For A Solid Foundation" src="http://videos.videopress.com/6M6GV0Kx/video-b5c0c52b9e_std.original.jpg" width="160" height="120" /></a></div>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Wed, 26 Mar 2014 18:22:27 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:12:"WordPress.tv";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:28;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:73:"WordPress.tv: Rick Radko: Tips and Tricks For Building Multilingual Sites";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wordpress.tv/?p=33385";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:90:"http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/26/rick-radko-tips-and-tricks-for-building-multilingual-sites/";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:695:"<div id="v-99oE3aWm-1" class="video-player">\n</div><br />  <a rel="nofollow" href="http://feeds.wordpress.com/1.0/gocomments/wptv.wordpress.com/33385/"><img alt="" border="0" src="http://feeds.wordpress.com/1.0/comments/wptv.wordpress.com/33385/" /></a> <img alt="" border="0" src="http://stats.wordpress.com/b.gif?host=wordpress.tv&blog=5089392&post=33385&subd=wptv&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /><div><a href="http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/26/rick-radko-tips-and-tricks-for-building-multilingual-sites/"><img alt="Rick Radko: Tips and Tricks For Building Multilingual Sites" src="http://videos.videopress.com/99oE3aWm/video-4fe497f51b_std.original.jpg" width="160" height="120" /></a></div>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Wed, 26 Mar 2014 18:20:57 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:12:"WordPress.tv";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:29;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:67:"WPTavern: Why Showing The WordPress Username Is Not A Security Risk";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19489";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:178:"http://wptavern.com/why-showing-the-wordpress-username-is-not-a-security-risk?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=why-showing-the-wordpress-username-is-not-a-security-risk";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:5863:"<p>When we talk about the <a title="http://codex.wordpress.org/Hardening_WordPress" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Hardening_WordPress">basics of WordPress security</a>, we always tell you to use a very strong password. The recently added <a title="http://wptavern.com/ridiculously-smart-password-meter-coming-to-wordpress-3-7" href="http://wptavern.com/ridiculously-smart-password-meter-coming-to-wordpress-3-7">password strength meter</a> helps to facilitate the process. But what about usernames? WordPress offers a way to change your display name which acts as a username alias. However, it doesn&#8217;t hide the username since it&#8217;s used within the URL and can&#8217;t be changed. For example, http://wptavern.com/author/username is always my account, despite what my display name is.</p>\n<div id="attachment_19732" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/LeakyUsernamesFeaturedImage.png" rel="prettyphoto[19489]"><img class="size-full wp-image-19732" alt="Leaky Usernames Featured Image" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/LeakyUsernamesFeaturedImage.png" width="638" height="200" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">photo credit: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kk/23390123/">Kris Krug</a> &#8211; <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/">cc</a></p></div>\n<p>Some argue the leaking of usernames is a security risk. Dion Hulse, a core contributor to WordPress, explained the reasoning behind leaked usernames in a <a title="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/20235#comment:7" href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/20235#comment:7">trac ticket</a> 19 months ago.</p>\n<blockquote><p>It has been stated in previous tickets, &#8220;leaking&#8221; of the username is not deemed a security issue by WordPress.org, as it&#8217;s a conscious decision to use the username as the slug in the URL. If you don&#8217;t like this default behaviour, there are plugins in the repository which allow you to change the url format to your preferred layout.</p>\n<p>Instead of attempting to provide security by forcing people to guess your username, you should be focusing on improving passwords, and/or considering two-factor authentication (ie. Google Authenticator) if your passwords are known to be insecure and/or weak.</p></blockquote>\n<p>While not exactly the same scenario, <a title="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/3708" href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/3708">this trac ticket</a> from seven years ago indicates how long the consensus has been around. The username is treated as common knowledge since it&#8217;s not difficult to determine. When I asked Andrew Nacin, lead developer for WordPress 3.9, whether the information shared by Hulse is still accurate, he said, &#8220;It&#8217;s fairly similar language we use when replying to security inquiries.&#8221; He then offered similar advice, &#8220;Create a strong password. Then, instead of playing games with your username, use a <a title="http://codex.wordpress.org/Two_Step_Authentication" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Two_Step_Authentication">two-factor authentication</a> plugin.&#8221;</p>\n<h3>What Is Two-Factor Authentication?</h3>\n<p>Logging in with a password is considered single-step authentication. It relies only on something you know. Two-step authentication, by definition, is a system where you use two of the three possible factors to prove your identity, instead of just one. In practice, however, current two-step implementations still rely on a password you know, but use your phone or another device to authenticate with something you have.</p>\n<h3>Two-Factor Authentication Using Jetpack Single Sign On and WordPress.com</h3>\n<p>Jetpack comes with a module called <a title="http://jetpack.me/support/sso/" href="http://jetpack.me/support/sso/">Single Sign On</a>. When activated, it allows visitors to use their WordPress.com login credentials to register accounts on self-hosted WordPress sites. This is important because users of WordPress.com have the ability to turn on two-factor authentication for their account.</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/TwoFactorEnabled.png" rel="prettyphoto[19489]"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-19623" alt="Two-Factor Authentication Enabled" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/TwoFactorEnabled-500x214.png" width="500" height="214" /></a></p>\n<p>By enabling two-factor authentication on WordPress.com, the account will be protected when used to register with any WordPress site using the single sign on module, whether or not it&#8217;s using a two-factor authentication plugin.</p>\n<h4>Alternative Two-Factor Authentication Plugins</h4>\n<p>There are plenty of alternatives to using WordPress.com and the single sign on module. A search of the plugin repository for two-factor authentication plugins <a title="http://wordpress.org/plugins/search.php?q=two-factor+authentication" href="http://wordpress.org/plugins/search.php?q=two-factor+authentication">shows 40 results</a>. I asked Brennen Byrne, co-founder of <a title="http://getclef.com/" href="http://getclef.com/">Clef,</a> what advice he has for those looking to add two-factor authentication to their site.</p>\n<blockquote><p>When deciding on a two-factor authentication plugin, you should look for one that is well maintained and frequently updated. Two-factor requires that you trust the sender of your messages, so you shouldn&#8217;t use a plugin that&#8217;s out of date or someone&#8217;s side-project.</p></blockquote>\n<p><a title="http://vip.wordpress.com/security/" href="http://vip.wordpress.com/security/">WordPress.com VIP</a> specifies passwords as the weakest link in the security of anything you do online. Two-factor authentication is an easy step you can take to make your logins more secure.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Wed, 26 Mar 2014 17:17:45 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Jeff Chandler";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:30;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:29:"Matt: Million Dollar Link Rot";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:21:"http://ma.tt/?p=43670";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:45:"http://ma.tt/2014/03/million-dollar-link-rot/";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:337:"<p>The Quartz finds that <a href="http://qz.com/191794/the-million-dollar-homepage-still-exists-but-22-of-it-has-rotted-away/">The Million Dollar Homepage still exists, but 22% of it has rotted away</a>. BTW, Alex Tew&#8217;s new venture is <a href="http://www.calm.com/">Calm.com</a> which is one of my favorite sites/services/apps.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Wed, 26 Mar 2014 15:43:20 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:14:"Matt Mullenweg";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:31;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:63:"WPTavern: WordPress Smiley Wars: Will Core Adopt New Emoticons?";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19730";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:166:"http://wptavern.com/wordpress-smiley-wars-will-core-adopt-new-emoticons?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=wordpress-smiley-wars-will-core-adopt-new-emoticons";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:10693:"<p>Over the past 30 years, emoticons have become a staple of digital communication. People rely on the smiley to add tone and feeling, which are often absent when communicating online. This is especially important in the case of text messaging and micro-blogging applications like Twitter where characters are limited. An emoticon can make all the difference between what might be perceived as a malicious jab vs. a good-natured joke.</p>\n<p>The controversy surrounding WordPress&#8217; built-in support for smilies has surfaced again in light of WordPress.com introducing a new set of <a href="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-com-gets-new-standard-and-secret-emoticons" target="_blank">modernized smilies</a>. If you&#8217;ve had smilies turned off in WordPress, and have always kept them turned off, then this discussion doesn&#8217;t affect you. But for the millions of WordPress sites where content creators have embraced smilies, the community is approaching another interesting fork in the road.</p>\n<h3>A Bit of Smiley History: WordPress Shows Its Teeth</h3>\n<p>In order to provide proper context for the current WordPress smilies debate, it&#8217;s important to explore a bit of smiley history. The mere mention of changing emoticons has always evoked a visceral reaction from the WordPress community.</p>\n<p><a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/10145" target="_blank">Ticket #10145</a> is home to a five-year-old debate that was recently reignited following the suggestion that core might update to use the new WordPress.com smilies. The ticket proposed that WordPress core replace the old smilies by incorporating a plugin containing what contributor <a href="https://profiles.wordpress.org/jdub" target="_blank">@jdub</a> believed to be <strong>&#8220;sexier (GPL and Public Domain) smilies from the GNOME and Tango icon themes.&#8221;</strong></p>\n<div id="attachment_19760" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/tango-gnome-smilies.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19730]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/tango-gnome-smilies.jpg" alt="Tango/GNOME Smilies" width="800" height="440" class="size-full wp-image-19760" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Tango/GNOME Smilies</p></div>\n<p>Without any discussion, the new smilies were unilaterally imposed upon everyone, as outlined in Jeff Chandler&#8217;s &#8220;<a href="http://wptavern.com/nothing-to-smile-about" target="_blank">Nothing To Smile About</a>,&#8221; an account of how the new emoticons ended up in core.</p>\n<p>They were added to WordPress.com without any announcement. Users were <a href="http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic/new-smilies" target="_blank">up in arms over the changes to smilies</a>, lamenting that the new emoticons appeared to be <strong>&#8220;cheap and cruel&#8221;</strong> in their expressions. Members described them as <strong>&#8220;hostile&#8221;</strong> and <strong>&#8220;full of teeth.&#8221;</strong> That support thread is a gem in terms of WordPress smiley history, with several members resorting to verse in order to express dissatisfaction with the new emoticons.</p>\n<p>Matt Mullenweg <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/10145#comment:23" target="_blank">proposed</a> that WordPress revert to the old smilies and instead make it easier for plugin developers to add custom smiley packs.</p>\n<blockquote><p>I suggest we go back to the old smilies in core, and have a canonical plugin for switching smilies that ships with as many open source smiley packs as possible. If we need a filter to do this more elegantly, let&#8217;s add it.</p></blockquote>\n<p>The Tango/GNOME smilies were then <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/10145#comment:27" target="_blank">reverted</a> to the old ones:</p>\n<div id="attachment_19753" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-revert.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19730]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-revert.jpg" alt="Tango/GNOME smilies reverted" width="806" height="255" class="size-full wp-image-19753" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Tango/GNOME smilies reverted</p></div>\n<p>As a result, <a href="https://codex.wordpress.org/Version_2.9" target="_blank">WordPress 2.9</a>, released in December of 2009, introduced the &#8216;<a href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Using_Smilies#How_Can_I_Have_Different_Smiley_Images_Appear.3F" target="_blank">smilies_src</a>&#8216; filter so plugins could better add custom smilies.</p>\n<h3>Smiley Wars Part 2: The Demand for Retina Smilies</h3>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-comparison1.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19730]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-comparison1.jpg" alt="smilies-comparison" width="800" height="289" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19723" /></a></p>\n<p><a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970" target="_blank">Ticket #24970</a> revives the smiley debate, five years later, proposing that WordPress update the emoticons to be suitable for retina displays. Several commenters on the ticket are in favor of using the new WordPress.com smilies, which is already a possibility thanks to a <a href="http://wptavern.com/give-wordpress-smilies-a-face-lift-new-plugin-adds-wordpress-com-emoticons-to-self-hosted-sites" target="_blank">plugin</a> created by Janneke Van Dorpe.</p>\n<p>Samuel &#8220;Otto&#8221; Wood, author of the <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/attachment/ticket/10145/srcurl.diff" target="_blank">smilies_src filter patch</a> applied during the Tango/GNOME era, <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970#comment:11" target="_blank">voiced his renewed opposition</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>-100 for including them in core. I love my existing smilies and will not be changing them.<br />\nIf you want to include them as an option and thus add a new configuration setting, sure. But changing the actual content of my site to something else will draw my ire same as it did when you tried it before.<br />\nNothing personal, but these are just as bad as the last time this was attempted. They look *wrong*.</p></blockquote>\n<h4>Smilies Are Content</h4>\n<p>Otto goes on to suggest that if people want the new emoticons, they should be added to Jetpack or another plugin instead of forcing the new designs on WordPress users. He <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970#comment:13" target="_blank">commented</a>:</p>\n<blockquote><p>Like it or not, those smilies are content. If you&#8217;re going to change them, you need to make sure you don&#8217;t change them on existing content without permission. That tends to tick people off&#8230;</p>\n<p>What I don&#8217;t want is for you to put them in core and thus arbitrarily rewrite the last X years of existing posts I already have to have these hideous new things instead.<br />\nRespect the content, respect the history.</p></blockquote>\n<p>The prospect of updating the emoticons means that WordPress users will either be forced to use the new smilies or use a plugin to revert them back.</p>\n<p>This debate highlights a hardware difference among WordPress users. Those using devices with retina displays are generally on board with updating the emoticons, since the current ones appear to be blurry. Supporters see new emoticons as a necessity of the modern era. WordPress lead developer Andrew Nacin <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970#comment:16" target="_blank">commented</a> on the benefits of updating the emoticons to a more modern set:</p>\n<blockquote><p>WordPress would benefit from HiDPI smilies. We would also benefit from shipping smilies that were designed in the last decade. But the fact is, there&#8217;s a lot of existing buy-in for something to change here. These smilies, if nothing else, provide a strong starting base.</p></blockquote>\n<p>In response to the possibility of core emoticons being up for change, Otto released a new plugin today called <a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/classic-smilies" target="_blank">Classic Smilies</a>, in order to future-proof content against core changes.</p>\n<p>&#8220;It seems that to prevent core from stepping on my content I now have no choice but to run preventative-measure plugins like these,&#8221; he said. &#8220;And that&#8217;s just a darned shame, in my opinion.&#8221;</p>\n<h3>Changing Smilies is No Small Thing</h3>\n<p>The <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970" target="_blank">ticket</a> for retina smilies is now home to a hot debate on where WordPress will go next in its support for emoticons. Any proposed changes will affect millions of users. If the Tango/GNOME smilies incident taught us anything, it&#8217;s that a healthy community discussion is valuable in understanding the implications of any proposed change.</p>\n<p>Big deal, they&#8217;re just smiley images, you might say. But smilies have a wider impact than we realize. They&#8217;re woven throughout posts and comments as part of a conversation and sometimes provide critical context for a discussion, much in the same way that images/media do. As one WordPress.com user commented five years ago, &#8220;Those little niceties can go a long way towards creating a pleasant comment thread.&#8221;</p>\n<p>A drastic change to smilies affects the tone of previous conversations. One might even argue that changing the face of the emoticons rewrites the history contained in older posts. In some cases this affects 10+ years worth of content. However, the number of years and posts affected doesn&#8217;t really matter. The fact is that millions of WordPress blogs are positively riddled with smilies. An update that forcibly changes this content may not be well-received.</p>\n<p>But how long can WordPress continue to ship emoticons that appear blurry as technology advances? The advent of retina displays has created an irresistible pull on software to support this technology. Modernizing WordPress for better use on all devices was one of the important factors in 3.8&#8242;s updated admin design. In this fast-moving digital age, a sentimental attachment to old designs is a death knell for any software.</p>\n<p>It isn&#8217;t likely that WordPress will add options for users to choose their smiley package, given its core <a href="http://wordpress.org/about/philosophy/" target="_blank">philosophy</a> of &#8220;Decisions, not Options&#8221;. Those who oppose updating the smilies to new ones will fight tooth and nail to keep them out, even if that means removing emoticons from the core altogether. How will this community-driven project solve the smiley dilemma?</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Wed, 26 Mar 2014 01:56:39 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Sarah Gooding";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:32;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:106:"WPTavern: Give WordPress Smilies a Face Lift: New Plugin Adds WordPress.com Emoticons to Self-Hosted Sites";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19694";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:254:"http://wptavern.com/give-wordpress-smilies-a-face-lift-new-plugin-adds-wordpress-com-emoticons-to-self-hosted-sites?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=give-wordpress-smilies-a-face-lift-new-plugin-adds-wordpress-com-emoticons-to-self-hosted-sites";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:2059:"<p>Are you in love with the new <a href="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-com-gets-new-standard-and-secret-emoticons" target="_blank">WordPress.com smilies</a>? Their modern look is a bit more expressive and endearing than the old emoticons. If you view them side-by-side, there is simply no comparison, especially when you zoom in:</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-comparison1.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19694]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-comparison1.jpg" alt="smilies-comparison" width="800" height="289" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19723" /></a></p>\n<p>Although there is a <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970" target="_blank">ticket</a> open for updating WordPress core emoticons for self-hosted sites, there&#8217;s no telling when that might move forward. In the meantime, if you cannot wait to get the new smilies, <a href="http://jannekevandorpe.com/" target="_blank">Janneke Van Dorpe</a> has created a plugin that adds them to self-hosted WordPress sites, essentially filtering the old ones to convert them to the set used on WordPress.com.</p>\n<p>The <a href="https://github.com/avryl/new-smileys" target="_blank">New WordPress.com Smileys</a> plugin is hosted on github. If you view the <a href="https://github.com/avryl/new-smileys/blob/master/new-smileys.php" target="_blank">code</a> for the plugin, you can see the whole list of smilies included. It works in just the same way as the emoticons on WordPress.com.</p>\n<p>I tested the plugin and found no issues. All of the standard and secret emoticons work as advertised. Many thanks to Janneke Van Dorpe for putting it out there for others to use. If you frequently use emoticons within WordPress, adding this plugin will instantly give all your old smilies a face lift. There&#8217;s no need to wait for modern smilies to arrive in the WordPress core. Download the <a href="https://github.com/avryl/new-smileys" target="_blank">New WordPress.com Smileys</a> plugin from github to get them now.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Tue, 25 Mar 2014 18:45:51 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Sarah Gooding";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:33;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:55:"WPTavern: Qik Is Shutting Down, How To Save Your Videos";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19671";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:152:"http://wptavern.com/qik-is-shutting-down-how-to-save-your-videos?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=qik-is-shutting-down-how-to-save-your-videos";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:4127:"<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/QikLogo.png" rel="prettyphoto[19671]"><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-19697" alt="Qik Logo" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/QikLogo.png" width="134" height="94" /></a>Founded in 2006, <a title="https://qik.com/" href="https://qik.com/">Qik</a> enabled mobile phone users to share live video with their friends, family and followers. In January of 2011, the company was <a title="http://mashable.com/2011/01/06/skype-acquires-qik-rumor/" href="http://mashable.com/2011/01/06/skype-acquires-qik-rumor/">acquired by Skype</a>. Three years after announcing the acquisition, the company <a title="http://support.qik.com/entries/26205425-Qik-service-retiring-in-April-2014-IMPORTANT-PLEASE-READ" href="http://support.qik.com/entries/26205425-Qik-service-retiring-in-April-2014-IMPORTANT-PLEASE-READ">has announced</a> they will shutdown the service on <strong>April 30, 2014</strong>. The shut down means all mobile apps will cease to function and all of the hosted videos will no longer be available.</p>\n<h3>oEmbed Support For Qik Will Be Removed In WordPress 3.9</h3>\n<p>WordPress supports <a title="http://codex.wordpress.org/Embeds" href="http://codex.wordpress.org/Embeds">oEmbeds</a> to make it easy to embed content from white listed services. For example, instead of using the embed code provided by YouTube, simply add the video URL into a post or page and WordPress will automatically turn it into embedded content. WordPress currently supports oEmbeds for Qik but they will be <a title="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/27302" href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/27302">removed in WordPress 3.9</a>.</p>\n<div id="attachment_19699" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/AuthorizeYouTubeQik.png" rel="prettyphoto[19671]"><img class="size-large wp-image-19699" alt="Step One In Moving Qik Videos To YouTube" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/AuthorizeYouTubeQik-500x190.png" width="500" height="190" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Step One In Moving Qik Videos To YouTube</p></div>\n<p>To save your videos, Qik recommends <a title="http://support.qik.com/entries/305417-How-can-I-download-Qik-videos-to-my-computer-" href="http://support.qik.com/entries/305417-How-can-I-download-Qik-videos-to-my-computer-">downloading them</a> and either storing them on a local storage medium or on <a title="https://skydrive.live.com/" href="https://skydrive.live.com/">SkyDrive</a> if you have a Microsoft account. Alternatively, you can use the <a title="http://support.qik.com/entries/310862-Sharing-to-YouTube" href="http://support.qik.com/entries/310862-Sharing-to-YouTube">YouTube feature</a> to move videos to YouTube. Videos that are embedded into posts or pages will soon show a <strong>video currently not available</strong> error. In April, the embedded flash player and videos will be removed. Whether it&#8217;s a video URL or the embed code, both will need to be removed from posts to prevent passive errors from showing in browsers.</p>\n<h3>The Best Time To Own Your Content Is Now</h3>\n<p><a title="http://mashable.com/2011/01/06/skype-acquires-qik-rumor/" href="http://mashable.com/2011/01/06/skype-acquires-qik-rumor/">According to Mashable</a>, Qik&#8217;s userbase reached 5 million users in 2010. With that many users, it&#8217;s inevitable a lot of videos will be lost forever, never to be viewed again. This is the risk anyone takes when they host their content on a third-party site instead of <a title="http://wpshout.com/own-your-content-wordpress/" href="http://wpshout.com/own-your-content-wordpress/">owning it</a>. This holds true no matter how large and or successful a service becomes.</p>\n<p>That&#8217;s not to say you shouldn&#8217;t use YouTube or any other third-party service. They&#8217;re a great asset to the web and give people access to an incredibly large and diverse audience. My rule of thumb is to always have a backup copy of your original works and do not trust a third-party to have your best interests in mind.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Tue, 25 Mar 2014 18:30:35 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Jeff Chandler";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:34;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:73:"WPTavern: Casper: A Free Ghost-Style WordPress Theme Based on Underscores";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19657";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:188:"http://wptavern.com/casper-a-free-ghost-style-wordpress-theme-based-on-underscores?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=casper-a-free-ghost-style-wordpress-theme-based-on-underscores";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:2640:"<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/casper.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19657]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/casper.jpg" alt="casper" width="838" height="349" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19659" /></a></p>\n<p><a href="http://lacymorrow.com/projects/casper/" target="_blank">Casper</a> is a new theme for WordPress that is essentially a port of the default blogging theme for <a href="https://ghost.org/" target="_blank">Ghost</a>. Lacy Morrow built the theme using <a href="http://underscores.me/" target="_blank">Underscores</a> as a base. Morrow said that the goal for his theme was to approximate Ghost&#8217;s default theme while incorporating WordPress-specific features:</p>\n<blockquote><p>The goal of this project is to emulate the gorgeous theme while taking advantage of features exclusive to the WordPress framework.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Responsive images in the theme are handled by a lightweight (1kb) <a href="https://github.com/kvendrik/responsive-images.js" target="_blank">script</a> that utilizes image replacement to load the correct image size for the visitor&#8217;s device.</p>\n<p>The ability to add your own social URLs is built into the customizer, along with a handful of other options that enable you to:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Upload your own logo</li>\n<li>Add a custom background image</li>\n<li>Customize the header background, text, link and hover colors</li>\n<li>Options to display header on all pages, make logo circular and frame logo image</li>\n</ul>\n<p>While testing the theme, I noticed the header disappears on single posts. I&#8217;m not sure if its disappearance is a ghost-like feature or a bug. However, if you go into the customizer and select to display the header on all pages, the problem is easily solved.</p>\n<p>Check out the <a href="http://lacymorrow.com/projects/casper/" target="_blank">live demo</a> of Casper to see it in action. The theme also includes specific styling for quotes and code blocks. Morrow created the demo content using Jetpack&#8217;s <a href="http://jetpack.me/support/markdown/" target="_blank">Markdown module</a>, but Markdown is not required in order to use the theme.</p>\n<p>Casper is a fast-loading super minimalist WordPress theme that you can easily customize to add your own personality. <a href="https://github.com/lacymorrow/casper-wp" target="_blank">Download</a> it from github and upload the casper-wp folder to your WordPress themes directory. If you&#8217;d like to report a bug, request a feature or contribute to the code, get in touch with <a href="http://lacymorrow.com/" target="_blank">Lacy Morrow</a>.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Tue, 25 Mar 2014 04:27:31 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Sarah Gooding";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:35;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:97:"WPTavern: Help Contribute To The Official WordPress Developer Resource By Testing Code References";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19214";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:238:"http://wptavern.com/help-contribute-to-the-official-wordpress-developer-resource-by-testing-code-references?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=help-contribute-to-the-official-wordpress-developer-resource-by-testing-code-references";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:2738:"<p>Announced at WordCamp San Francisco during Matt Mullenweg&#8217;s <a title="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=al_Saklwq48" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=al_Saklwq48">State of The Word 2013 </a>presentation, <a title="http://developer.wordpress.org/" href="http://developer.wordpress.org/">developer.wordpress.org</a> will host educational tools for developers in the form of handbooks and code referencing material.</p>\n<p>It will be the go-to place to discover WordPress best practices. Since educational materials surrounding WordPress are spread across the web, it&#8217;s hard for developers to determine which pieces of information are considered best practice. One of the potential side effects to having all of the WordPress best practices in one place is the increased chance themes and plugins will be better developed.</p>\n<div id="attachment_19656" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/DeveloperResourceSiteBeta.png" rel="prettyphoto[19214]"><img class="size-large wp-image-19656" alt="Potentially How The New Site Will Look" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/DeveloperResourceSiteBeta-500x295.png" width="500" height="295" /></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Potentially How The New Site Will Look</p></div>\n<p>When asked what the main priority is to help get the site completed, Siobhan McKeown, a volunteer for the project said, &#8220;We&#8217;re working on getting the parser finished so the priority is getting that tested. As soon as it&#8217;s done and it&#8217;s up and running we&#8217;ll be looking for people to work on the theme.&#8221;</p>\n<p>The <a title="http://developer.rarst.net/reference/" href="http://developer.rarst.net/reference/">code reference</a> is close to being finished but the team would like your help to give it a final push to get it out the door. The items that need attention are as follows:</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Testing <a href="https://github.com/rmccue/WP-Parser">WP-Parser</a> – <a href="http://make.wordpress.org/docs/handbook/projects/devhub/#setting-up-your-development-environment">instructions on setting it up here.</a></li>\n<li><a href="https://github.com/rmccue/WP-Parser/issues">Fixing issues with WP-Parser</a></li>\n<li>Working on the code reference side of the website</li>\n<li>Helping to finish off the handbook themes</li>\n</ol>\n<p>If <a title="http://make.wordpress.org/core/2014/03/18/help-with-developer-wordpress-org/" href="http://make.wordpress.org/core/2014/03/18/help-with-developer-wordpress-org/">you&#8217;re interested in helping out</a>, the team meets up regularly on Tuesdays at 19:00 UTC in the #wordpress-sfd IRC channel. Interested contributors will also be added to a Skype channel.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Tue, 25 Mar 2014 00:45:56 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:13:"Jeff Chandler";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:36;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:122:"WordPress.tv: Interview de Kim Gjerstad, orateur de la conférence “Vivre d’une extension ? Sarah Semark: Build a Website On The Moon: WordPress Development From Anywhere";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wordpress.tv/?p=33373";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:108:"http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/24/sarah-semark-build-a-website-on-the-moon-wordpress-development-from-anywhere/";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:732:"<div id="v-PR18d8M9-1" class="video-player">\n</div><br />  <a rel="nofollow" href="http://feeds.wordpress.com/1.0/gocomments/wptv.wordpress.com/33373/"><img alt="" border="0" Anywhere" src="http://videos.videopress.com/PR18d8M9/video-4b1bea683b_std.original.jpg" width="160" height="120" /></a></div>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 18:14:09 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:12:"WordPress.tv";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:42;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:62:"WPTavern: WordPress.com Gets New Standard and Secret Emoticons";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19326";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:168:"http://wptavern.com/wordpress-com-gets-new-standard-and-secret-emoticons?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=wordpress-com-gets-new-standard-and-secret-emoticons";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:4296:"<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/emoticons.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19326]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/emoticons.jpg" alt="emoticons" width="971" height="366" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19647" /></a></p>\n<p>Emoticons are believed to have been <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/technology/2011/09/happy-birthday-emoticon/" target="_blank">invented in 1982</a> by Scott Fahlman, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University, who suggested that they be used on &#8220;computer bulletin boards.&#8221; Though not widely used at that time, emoticon usage exploded with the popularity of AOL’s Instant Messenger in the 1990&#8242;s.</p>\n<p>Now, more than 30 years later, emoticons are still going strong thanks to text and chat applications. They&#8217;re also still widely used in blogs. In fact, WordPress.com just gave their smilies a <a href="http://en.blog.wordpress.com/2014/03/21/new-emoticons/" target="_blank">redesign</a> to be &#8220;cleaner, simpler, bigger, more expressive, and modern.&#8221; The new emoticons were created to use vector graphics, which means that when you zoom in or view them on retina displays, they will still display beautifully.</p>\n<h3>Standard and Secret Emoticons on WordPress.com</h3>\n<p>WordPress.com <a href="http://en.support.wordpress.com/smilies/" target="_blank">smilies documentation</a> includes all your standard updated smilies:</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-standard.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19326]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-standard.jpg" alt="smilies-standard" width="682" height="119" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19637" /></a></p>\n<p>You can turn them on by navigating to <strong>Settings > Writing Settings</strong>:</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smiley-settings.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19326]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smiley-settings.jpg" alt="smiley-settings" width="742" height="148" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19349" /></a></p>\n<p>Although there is no smiley-chooser interface in the post editor, hovering over an emoticon in use on WordPress.com will display a tooltip with the necessary code to make that particular smiley. Additionally, most of the smilies also work with dashes for noses.</p>\n<p>At the end of the <a href="http://en.blog.wordpress.com/2014/03/19/new-emoticons/" target="_blank">announcement</a>, Automattic designer Joen Asmussen hints at the existence of secret smileys: <strong>&#8220;We also created a few secret emoticons for you to discover. Good luck finding them! ;)&#8221;</strong></p>\n<p>However, there&#8217;s no easy way to discover the secret ones unless someone shows you. The following are the secret smilies, as originally <a href="http://jannekevandorpe.com/2014/03/19/secret-new-wordpress-smileys/" target="_blank">posted</a> by Janneke Van Dorpe. They are undoubtedly a tribute to the fuel that powers WordPress.com developers:</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-secret.jpg" rel="prettyphoto[19326]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/smilies-secret.jpg" alt="smilies-secret" width="399" height="95" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19638" /></a></p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s how you make them:</p>\n<pre>(W) &gt;-I |_| :developer: :burrito:</pre>\n<p>The design team at WordPress.com is working on expanding the collection of smilies, so there will be more to add to this list in the future.</p>\n<h3>Will Self-Hosted WordPress Sites Get Updated Emoticons?</h3>\n<p>If you&#8217;re a self-hosted WordPress site owner who is swooning over the new emoticons, you&#8217;ll be glad to know that there is a <a href="https://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/24970" target="_blank">ticket to update emoticons</a> in core, originally opened eight months ago. WordPress needs retina-ready smilies, but it&#8217;s not yet clear whether the new WordPress.com emoticons are a good option.</p>\n<p>However, the new, modernized smilies have put this ticket back on everyone&#8217;s radar and we may see some action on it in the near feature. It looks like smilies are here to stay. Do you think they&#8217;ll be with us another 30 years?</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 18:08:24 Mo Jangda: Caching For Fun And Profit";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wordpress.tv/?p=33378";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:68:"http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/24/mo-jangda-caching-for-fun-and-profit/";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:651:"<div id="v-zZFfkWgg-1" class="video-player">\n</div><br />  <a rel="nofollow" href="http://feeds.wordpress.com/1.0/gocomments/wptv.wordpress.com/33378/"><img alt="" border="0" src="http://feeds.wordpress.com/1.0/comments/wptv.wordpress.com/33378/" /></a> <img alt="" border="0" src="http://stats.wordpress.com/b.gif?host=wordpress.tv&blog=5089392&post=33378&subd=wptv&ref=&feed=1" width="1" height="1" /><div><a href="http://wordpress.tv/2014/03/24/mo-jangda-caching-for-fun-and-profit/"><img alt="Mo Jangda: Caching For Fun And Profit" src="http://videos.videopress.com/zZFfkWgg/video-350095de34_std.original.jpg" width="160" height="120" /></a></div>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 18:03:06 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:12:"WordPress.tv";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:44;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:48:"Andrew Nacin: An hour to make government better";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:24:"http://nacin.com/?p=4215";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:62:"http://nacin.com/2014/03/24/an-hour-to-make-government-better/";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:3095:"<p>I had the pleasure last week of spending not quite an hour of my time at the U.S. General Services Administration reviewing the public APIs of three federal agencies. We all sat around a table and they let me rant while I worked to understand their documentation, tested their APIs, and discussed what could improve the developer experience. They took copious notes, had great questions, and were even deploying adjustments on the fly.</p>\n<p>In talking to GSA&#8217;s <a href="https://github.com/gbinal">Gray Brooks</a>, I learned dozens of federal agencies are lining up for these review sessions. It&#8217;s an exciting time to be a consumer of government data, and it makes me really happy that they&#8217;re encouraging citizens to actively shape this process. It was obvious how helpful it was for these government technologists to hear an outside perspective. If your local government is on the path of “Gov 2.0” see if you can offer even just a little bit of your time to share your expertise.</p>\n<p>Unlike someone like <a href="https://konklone.com/">Eric Mill</a> of <a href="http://sunlightfoundation.com/">Sunlight</a> (who also gave a round of feedback yesterday), I&#8217;m not a regular consumer of government APIs. But as a lead developer of WordPress, a citizen, and a taxpayer, I feel very strongly about an open, transparent, and efficient government; open government data; and an open web enriched by accessible APIs.</p>\n<address>You can follow the GSA&#8217;s efforts at <a href="https://18f.gsa.gov/">18f.gsa.gov</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/18f">@18f</a>, and <a href="http://github.com/18f">GitHub</a>. For the record, the U.S. agencies were <a href="http://www.foreignassistance.gov/">ForeignAssistance.gov</a> (<a href="http://www.state.gov/">State</a>/<a href="http://www.usaid.gov/">USAID</a>), <a href="http://www.fema.gov/">FEMA</a>, and the <a href="http://www.fda.gov/">FDA</a>.</address>\n<address><strong>Bonus: </strong>About three years ago, when <a href="http://ben.balter.com/">Ben Balter</a> was at the FCC, he wrote an <a href="http://www.fcc.gov/developers/api-terms-of-service">API Terms of Service</a> that was heavily inspired by WordPress.com&#8217;s own <a href="http://en.wordpress.com/tos/">TOS</a>. Ben is now a government evangelist at GitHub — where you <a href="https://github.com/Automattic/legalmattic">can now find</a> WordPress.com&#8217;s TOS. Anyway: it turns out that the TOS he wrote for the FCC is <a href="https://twitter.com/BenBalter/status/446346791697780736">now used by more than 20 other federal agencies</a>, and the <a href="https://github.com/18F/API-All-the-X/blob/dad44b9ecbb8b41cf3cdf85d5d19f888ad1578ae/developer_hub_kit.md#terms-of-service">GSA is pitching it</a> as a common template for all agencies. That&#8217;s quite the body of derivative work.</address>\n<p class="share-sfc-stc"><a href="http://twitter.com/share?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwp.me%2FpQEdq-15Z&count=horizontal&related=nacin&text=An%20hour%20to%20make%20government%20better" class="twitter-share-button"></a></p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 17:20:01 +0000";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}s:32:"http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/";a:1:{s:7:"creator";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:12:"Andrew Nacin";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}}}}i:45;a:6:{s:4:"data";s:13:"\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n	\n";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";s:5:"child";a:2:{s:0:"";a:5:{s:5:"title";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:83:"WPTavern: How I Solved My WordPress For iOS Two-Factor Authentication Login Problem";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19616";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:210:"http://wptavern.com/how-i-solved-my-wordpress-for-ios-two-factor-authentication-login-problem?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=how-i-solved-my-wordpress-for-ios-two-factor-authentication-login-problem";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:3919:"<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/TwoFactorEnabled.png" rel="prettyphoto[19616]"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-19623" alt="Two-Factor Authentication Enabled" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/TwoFactorEnabled-300x128.png" width="300" height="128" /></a>Over the weekend, we reported that <a title="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-for-ios-4-0-available-new-and-improved-stats" href="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-for-ios-4-0-available-new-and-improved-stats">WordPress For iOS 4.0</a> was released. Not only did I upgrade, but I also enabled the <a title="http://jetpack.me/support/sso/" href="http://jetpack.me/support/sso/">single-sign on Jetpack module</a> for WPTavern.com and <a title="http://en.support.wordpress.com/security/two-step-authentication/" href="http://en.support.wordpress.com/security/two-step-authentication/">two-factor authentication</a> for my WordPress.com user account. Within the comments of the post, <a title="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-for-ios-4-0-available-new-and-improved-stats#comment-53431" href="http://wptavern.com/wordpress-for-ios-4-0-available-new-and-improved-stats#comment-53431">Jonathan Lyman mentioned</a> WordPress For iOS is incompatible with two-factor authentication:</p>\n<blockquote><p>Just a small heads up for those who’ve never used the WordPress for iOS app before. If one has a two-factor authentication plugin active, the WordPress app will not be able to login to a self-hosted site.</p></blockquote>\n<h3>WordPress App Doesn&#8217;t Accept Login Credentials To WordPress.com</h3>\n<p>When trying to manage my self-hosted WordPress site within the app, I repeatedly received prompts to login to WordPress.com. Using the same password I use on my desktop didn&#8217;t work. No matter what I tried, I couldn&#8217;t successfully login to WordPress.com from within the mobile app.</p>\n<p>However, if I was quick enough, I could still browse comment notifications, create new posts, etc. I determined that only items within the app that require an authenticated connection to WordPress.com stopped functioning. While browsing the support forum, I discovered forum threads where other users<a title="http://ios.forums.wordpress.org/topic/cannot-login-with-ipad-app-self-hosted-2fa?replies=9" href="http://ios.forums.wordpress.org/topic/cannot-login-with-ipad-app-self-hosted-2fa?replies=9"> reported login issues</a> using two-factor authentication.</p>\n<h3>How I Solved The Problem</h3>\n<p>I logged out of WordPress.com using my desktop. I logged back in using my desktop, used the keycode given to me by the <a title="http://en.support.wordpress.com/security/two-step-authentication/#setup-with-google-authenticator" href="http://en.support.wordpress.com/security/two-step-authentication/#setup-with-google-authenticator">Google Authenticator app</a> and now,  stats work, as does the rest of the app without pestering me to login to WordPress.com.</p>\n<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/2FAGoogleAuthenticator.png" rel="prettyphoto[19616]"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-19625" alt="Google Authenticator" src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/2FAGoogleAuthenticator-500x343.png" width="500" height="343" /></a></p>\n<p>So if you&#8217;re repeatedly asked to login to WordPress.com after enabling two-factor authentication, I&#8217;d try logging out of WordPress.com using your desktop and login again. Then determine if the app detects your validated connection to WordPress.com. This solved the problem for me.</p>\n<p>If you still experience issues related to two-factor authentication, please report them using the <a title="http://ios.forums.wordpress.org/" href="http://ios.forums.wordpress.org/">WordPress For iOS Support forum</a>.</p>\n<p><strong>Has anyone else gone through the same experience after enabling two-factor authentication?</strong></p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 17:19:38 PhpStorm 8 To Add Official Support for WordPress";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"guid";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:28:"http://wptavern.com/?p=19590";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:4:"link";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:160:"http://wptavern.com/phpstorm-8-to-add-official-support-for-wordpress?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=phpstorm-8-to-add-official-support-for-wordpress";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:11:"description";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:2438:"<p><a href="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/phpstorm.png" rel="prettyphoto[19590]"><img src="http://wptavern.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/phpstorm.png" alt="phpstorm" width="910" height="507" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-19598" /></a></p>\n<p><a href="http://www.jetbrains.com/phpstorm/">PhpStorm</a> is a popular IDE that many developers depend on to code more efficiently, debug applications, and run unit tests with integrated version control and command-line tools. The upcoming version 8 will add <a href="http://blog.jetbrains.com/phpstorm/2014/03/wordpress-support-in-phpstorm-8-eap/" target="_blank">official support for WordPress</a>.</p>\n<p>According to a recent <a href="http://www.sitepoint.com/best-php-ide-2014-survey-results/">survey</a> conducted by SitePoint, PhpStorm is by far the most favored IDE among PHP developers in 2014. It captured the vote of nearly 40% surveyed, followed by Sublime Text (18.5%) and NetBeans (15.6%). PhpStorm was the clear all-around winner for both business and personal use, due to its speed, strong community, and support for a wide variety of languages and frameworks.</p>\n<p>PhpStorm has supported Drupal and other PHP frameworks for a couple of years and is now finally adding WordPress-specific development features. Version 8 will include:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>WordPress integration in PhpStorm for new plugins (with plugin skeleton) and existing projects</li>\n<li>WordPress code style</li>\n<li>Development environment configuration for WordPress</li>\n<li>Hooks support (Completion for registration functions parameters; Navigation from hook registration functions to hook invocation; Callbacks from hook registration; and other hooks-related features)</li>\n<li>Search on WordPress.org right from the editor</li>\n<li>WordPress command line tool WP-CLI integration</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If you want to give it a test run, version 8 is currently available via the <a href="http://confluence.jetbrains.com/display/PhpStorm/PhpStorm+Early+Access+Program" target="_blank">PhpStorm Early Access Program</a>. New users will appreciate the <a href="http://confluence.jetbrains.com/display/PhpStorm/WordPress+Development+using+PhpStorm" target="_blank">full tutorial</a> for configuring your development environment for WordPress projects. It will walk you through creating a new plugin and also has instructions for enabling WordPress integration for existing PhpStorm projects.</p>";s:7:"attribs";a:0:{}s:8:"xml_base";s:0:"";s:17:"xml_base_explicit";b:0;s:8:"xml_lang";s:0:"";}}s:7:"pubDate";a:1:{i:0;a:5:{s:4:"data";s:31:"Mon, 24 Mar 2014 06:30:48 #
# End of data contents of table `wp_options`
# --------------------------------------------------------

# --------------------------------------------------------
# Table: `wp_postmeta`
# --------------------------------------------------------


#
# Delete any existing table `wp_postmeta`
#

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `wp_postmeta`;


#
# Table structure of table `wp_postmeta`
#

CREATE TABLE `wp_postmeta` (
  `meta_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
  `post_id` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL default '0',
  `meta_key` varchar(255) default NULL,
  `meta_value` longtext,
  PRIMARY KEY  (`meta_id`),
  KEY `post_id` (`post_id`),
  KEY `meta_key` (`meta_key`)
) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=486 DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 ;

#
# Data contents of table `wp_postmeta`
#

#
# End of data contents of table `wp_postmeta`
# --------------------------------------------------------

# --------------------------------------------------------
# Table: `wp_posts`
# --------------------------------------------------------


#
# Delete any existing table `wp_posts`
#

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `wp_posts`;


#
# Table structure of table `wp_posts`
#

CREATE TABLE `wp_posts` (
  `ID` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
  `post_author` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL default '0',
  `post_date` datetime NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `post_date_gmt` datetime NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `post_content` longtext NOT NULL,
  `post_title` text NOT NULL,
  `post_excerpt` text NOT NULL,
  `post_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL default 'publish',
  `comment_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL default 'open',
  `ping_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL default 'open',
  `post_password` varchar(20) NOT NULL default '',
  `post_name` varchar(200) NOT NULL default '',
  `to_ping` text NOT NULL,
  `pinged` text NOT NULL,
  `post_modified` datetime NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `post_modified_gmt` datetime NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
  `post_content_filtered` longtext NOT NULL,
  `post_parent` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL default '0',
  `guid` varchar(255) NOT NULL default '',
  `menu_order` int(11) NOT NULL default '0',
  `post_type` varchar(20) NOT NULL default 'post',
  `post_mime_type` varchar(100) NOT NULL default '',
  `comment_count` bigint(20) NOT NULL default '0',
  PRIMARY KEY  (`ID`),
  KEY `post_name` (`post_name`),
  KEY `type_status_date` (`post_type`,`post_status`,`post_date`,`ID`),
  KEY `post_parent` (`post_parent`),
  KEY `post_author` (`post_author`)
) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=1042 DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 ;

#
# Data contents of table `wp_posts`
#

Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. To me, creation is the biggest part of my life and whenever I am working with media, I am truly happy.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">Email: coreynoble@hotmail.ca</p>\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">LinkedIn: http://lnkd.in/-95MyD</p>\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">Portfolio: http://www.nobleresolutions.ca</p>\r\n\r\n&nbsp;', 'The Team', '', 'inherit', 'open', 'open', '', '15-revision-v1', '', '', '2014-02-27 19:08:13', '2014-02-27 19:08:13', '', 15, 'http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/2014/02/27/15-revision-v1/', 0, 'revision', '', 0);

INSERT INTO `wp_posts` VALUES (110, 2, '2014-02-28 01:29:48', '2014-02-28 01:29:48', 'We are freelance web developers from London Ontario. After developing these skills for 4 years I decided to expand my knowledge and go to college to pursue a career in media. I have experience with video editing, website development and logo design. I can code a website from scratch and customise WordPress templates.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 460px; text-align:right;">Going to college to study Multi-Media Design and Production was one of the best decisions I made in my personal life. I have taken my passion for media and made it my career. I’ve been designing and creating clean, elegant, creative websites for two years and on the side I like to work on video effects and poster design projects.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; text-align:right;">Email: manannh5@gmail.ca</p>\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; text-align:right;">Portfolio: http://www.imaginebigdesign.ca</p>\r\n\r\n\r\n<a href="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-70" alt="CoreyCharacature" style="float: right; width: 150px;" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png" width="150" height="241" /></a>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">Hi I\'m Corey Noble. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px;">Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. I’ve been designing and creating clean, elegant, creative websites for two years and on the side I like to work on video effects and poster design projects.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; text-align:right; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;">manannh5@gmail.ca</p>\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; text-align:right; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;">http://www.imaginebigdesign.ca</p>\r\n\r\n\r\n<a href="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-70" alt="CoreyCharacature" style="float: right; width: 150px;" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png" width="150" height="241" /></a>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Hi I\'m Corey Noble. While many people don\'t know what they want to do as a career for the rest of their lives, I was lucky in knowing that I wanted to pursue the arts at a fairly young age. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. I’ve been designing and creating clean, elegant, creative websites for two years and on the side I like to work on video effects and poster design projects.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;"><a href="http://www.imaginebigdesign.ca" target="_blank" style="color:#277e9c;">Portfolio Website</a></p>\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;">manannh5@gmail.com</p>\r\n\r\n\r\n<a href="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-70" alt="CoreyCharacature" style="float: right; width: 150px;" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png" width="150" height="241" /></a>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Hi I\'m Corey Noble. While many people don\'t know what they want to do as a career for the rest of their lives, I was lucky in knowing that I wanted to pursue the arts at a fairly young age. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. I’ve been designing and creating clean, elegant, creative websites for two years and on the side I like to work on video effects and poster design projects.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; text-align: right; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;"><a href="http://www.imaginebigdesign.ca" target="_blank" style="color:#277e9c;">My portfolio website</a></p>\r\n<p style="float: right; text-align: right; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;">manannh5@gmail.com</p>\r\n<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-83" alt="Break" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Break1-300x2.png" width="630" height="2" />\r\n\r\n<a href="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-70" alt="CoreyCharacature" style="float: right; width: 150px;" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png" width="150" height="241" /></a>\r\n\r\n<h1>Manann Him</h1>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Hi I\'m Corey Noble. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Back then I enjoyed customizing profile pages on various social networking websites. After developing these skills for 4 years I decided to expand my knowledge and go to college to pursue a career in media. I have experience with video editing, website development and logo design. I can code a website from scratch and customise WordPress templates.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: right; width: 460px; text-align:centre;">Going to college to study Multi-Media Design and Production was one of the best decisions I made in my personal life. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; text-align:centre;">Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. To me, creation is the biggest part of my life and whenever I am working with media, I am truly happy.</p>\r\n\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;"><a href="http://www.nobleresolutions.ca" target="_blank" style="color:#277e9c;">My portfolio website</a></p>\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"><a href="http://lnkd.in/-95MyD" target="_blank" style="color:#277e9c;">My LinkedIn profile</a></p>\r\n<p style="float: left; width: 450px; margin: 0; padding: 0; color:#277e9c;">coreynoble@hotmail.ca</p>\r\n\r\n&nbsp;', 'The Team', '', 'inherit', 'open', 'open', '', '15-revision-v1', '', '', '2014-02-28 02:31:58', '2014-02-28 02:31:58', '', 15, 'http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/2014/02/28/15-revision-v1/', 0, 'revision', '', 0);

INSERT INTO `wp_posts` VALUES (344, 2, '2014-03-26 23:44:57', '2014-03-26 23:44:57', '<h1>About Us</h1>\n\n<p style="font-size: 17px; width: 95%; margin: 0; padding: 0; margin-bottom: 20px;  margin-left: 10px;">We are freelance web developers from London Ontario. Both graduates of the Multi-Media Design and Production program, as well as the 3D Animation and Character Design program at Fanshawe College. We have a great passion for creating media and put love into every pixel.</p>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-83" alt="Break" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Break1-300x2.png" style="width:100%; height:2px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"/>\n<h1 style="text-align: left; text-align: center; margin: 0; padding: 0;">Manann Him</h1>\n\n<img alt="ManannCharacature" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/ManannCharacature.png" style="float: left; width: 25%; margin-left: 10px; margin-top: 20px;"/>\n\n<p style="float: left; width: 68%; margin-left: 10px; font-size: 17px;">Hi I’m Manann Him. I am an enthusiastic, motivated and energetic individual with love and passion for creating media. I started learning HTML on my own when social media started to become popular. Back then I enjoyed customizing profile pages on various social networking websites. After developing these skills for 4 years I decided to expand my knowledge and go to college to pursue a career in media. I have experience with video editing, website development and logo design. I can code a website from scratch and customise WordPress templates.</p>\n\n<p style="float: left; width: 68%; margin-left: 10px; font-size: 17px;">Going to college to study Multi-Media Design and Production was one of the best decisions I made in my personal life. I have taken my passion for media and made it my career. I’ve been designing and creating clean, elegant, creative websites for two years and on the side I like to work on video effects and poster design projects.</p>\n</div>\n\n<div style="float: left; width: 100%;">\n<p style="color:#277e9c; font-size: 20px; margin: 0; padding: 0; margin-top: 3px; margin-left: 10px;"><a href="http://www.imaginebigdesign.ca" target="_blank" style="color:#277e9c;">My portfolio website</a></p>\n</div>\n<div style="float: left; width: 100%;">\n<p style="color:#277e9c; font-size: 20px; margin: 0; padding: 0; margin-top: 3px; margin-left: 10px; margin-bottom: 20px;">manannh5@gmail.com</p>\n</div>\n\n<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-83" alt="Break" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Break1-300x2.png" style="width:100%; height:2px; margin: 0; padding: 0;"/>\n<div style="width: 100%;">\n<h1 style="text-align: left; font-size: 35px; text-align: center; margin: 0; padding: 0;">Corey Noble</h1>\n\n<img alt="CoreyCharacature" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/CoreyCharacature.png" style="float: left; width: 25%; margin-left: 10px; margin-top: 20px;"/>\n\n<p style="float: left; width: 68%; margin-left: 10px; font-size: 17px;">Hi I\'m Corey Noble. While many people don\'t know what they want to do as a career for the rest of their lives, I was lucky in knowing that I wanted to pursue the arts at a fairly young age. We have a great passion for creating media and put love into every pixel.</p>\r\n\r\n<img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-83" alt="Break" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Break1-300x2.png" style="width:100%; height:2px;"/>\r\n\r\n<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-71" alt="ManannCharacature" src="http://0391e66.netsolhost.com/RightChoice/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/ManannCharacature.png"/>\r\n\r\n<h1>Manann Him</h1>\r\n\r\n<p>Hi I’m Manann Him. Back then I enjoyed customizing profile pages on various social networking websites. After developing these skills for 4 years I decided to expand my knowledge and go to college to pursue a career in media. I have experience with video editing, website development and logo design. I can code a website from scratch and customise WordPress templates.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Going to college to study Multi-Media Design and Production was one of the best decisions I made in my personal life. While many people don\'t know what they want to do as a career for the rest of their lives, I was lucky in knowing that I wanted to pursue the arts at a fairly young age. I took every possible art and programming course in high-school and promptly went to college to learn about website and media development. I also took a 3D animation program. Upon graduating my final year I was an IOS and Android game developer. Since then I have been working as a freelance website developer and enhancing my 3D skills through personal works and online competitions.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>Although I have finished my education, I am never done learning and enhancing my technical and artistic talents. INSERT INTO `wp_posts` VALUES (360, 2, '2014-03-16 18:58:17', '2014-03-16 18:58:17', '<p>We are freelance web developers from London Ontario.
